criteria: Graphing a System of Linear Inequalities
descriptions: No attempt to graph the inequality or the graph is completely incorrect.
Attempts to graph the inequality but makes significant errors in identifying the line or shading the correct region.
Graphs the line correctly but incorrectly shades the region or uses the wrong type of line (solid vs. dashed).
Graphs the line correctly and shades the correct region, but makes a minor error, such as not extending the shading far enough.
Accurately graphs the line and shades the correct region, using the appropriate type of line (solid or dashed).
Graphs the solution to the linear inequality in two variables as a half-plane with complete accuracy and clarity, including correct boundary line and shading; presents the graph neatly and precisely.
No attempt to graph the system of inequalities or the graph is completely incorrect.
Attempts to graph the system but struggles to graph individual inequalities correctly.
Graphs each inequality somewhat correctly but does not accurately identify the intersection of the half-planes.
Graphs each inequality mostly correctly and identifies the intersection, but makes minor shading errors.
Accurately graphs each inequality and correctly identifies the intersection of the corresponding half-planes.

Graphs the solution set to a system of linear inequalities in two variables with complete accuracy, clearly indicating the intersection of the corresponding half-planes; uses different colors or line styles to distinguish the inequalities, presenting the graph in a clear, understandable manner.
Shows no understanding of how to represent strict vs. non-strict inequalities graphically.
Shows limited understanding, consistently using the wrong type of line (solid/dashed) or not understanding when to exclude the boundary.
Understands the concept but makes frequent errors in applying it to specific problems.
Generally uses the correct type of line but occasionally makes errors with strict inequalities.
Consistently uses the correct type of line (solid for ≤/≥, dashed for </>) to represent strict and non-strict inequalities.

Demonstrates a comprehensive understanding of boundary conditions by flawlessly representing strict and non-strict inequalities graphically, clearly differentiating between included and excluded boundaries in all scenarios.
